title: Trump says Whistle-blower's source who listened to Ukraine phone call might be a SPY
text:
President Donald Trump on Wednesday once again put forward the allegation that a person who provided information to a whistle-blower about his own call with the president of Ukraine might be a 'spy.'

The president has repeatedly invoked spy-craft in remarks blasting the whistle-blower who revealed his request of a 'favor' to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky – a probe related to the 2016 elections and one related to the Bidens.

Speaking at the White House, he said: 'I’d like to find, who’s the person in between the whistle-blower and hearing about the conversation.'

President Trump once again raised allegations that the person who gave a whistle-blower information about his infamous Ukraine phone call could be a 'spy'

The whistle-blower acknowledges in his report, which jump-started a House impeachment investigation, that he got the information about the call from other U.S. government officials.

As many as a dozen people were on the call, including national security staff, note-takers, an aide to Vice President Mike Pence, and Trump loyalist Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

'The conversation I think was a perfect conversation,' said Trump, although House Democrats are probing whether it constituted an abuse of power while seeking evidence of any quid pro quo, which Trump denies happened.

Trump said there should be an investigation of the matter, and Rep. Mark Meadows of North Carolina nodded in response

Trump blasted the 'spy' at an event where he signed an executive order on 'transparency'

'But who's the person giving this information? If that person exists -- I'm not sure that person exists, but I think it’s important.'

Then he turned to Freedom Caucus head Rep. Mark Meadows of North Carolina, who was standing behind him at an event. 'And I say this to Congress. I think it's important to find out who that person is. Because we could have a spy. I don't want spies,' Trump said.

It was not immediately clear if he meant a U.S. official had actually engaged in espionage for a foreign power, or he was referring to properly credentialed people listening in on the call. The New York Times reported that a second whistle-blower also complained about the 'crazy' phone call after it happened.

In remarks to UN workers last month soon after he ordered the release of the transcript of his call Trump raised the spy allegation in remarks caught on video.

Trump said: 'I want to know who's the person, who's the person who gave the whistle-blower the information? Because that's close to a spy.' He continued: 'You know what we used to do in the old days when we were smart? Right? The spies and treason, we used to handle it a little differently than we do now,' he said, referencing execution.

House Intelligence chairman Rep. Adam Schiff has invited the whistle-blower to testify to his committee

Trump's attack came as CBS published what it said was the full report provided by the whistle-blower.

The whistle-blower reported speaking to a an unnamed White House official for a few minutes after Trump's July 25 call with the Ukrainian president. The official described a call that was "crazy," "frightening" and "completely lacking in substance related to national security," according to the report.

The official was 'visibly shaken by what had transpired and seemed keen to inform a trusted colleague within the U.S. national security apparatus about the call.'

According to the whistle-blower's notes: 'The official stated that there was already a conversation underway with White House lawyers about how to handle the discussion because, in the official's view, the President had clearly committed a criminal act by urging a foreign power to investigate a U.S. person for the purposes of advancing his own reelection bid in 2020.'
description: President Donald Trump on Wednesday once again put forward the allegation that a person who provided information to a whistle-blower about his own call with the president of Ukraine might be a 'spy.'
authors: Deputy U.S. Political Editor For Dailymail.Com
